w0010-p0026-01:
Tomorrow’s Energy...

Pha hhh LLL Lf
Lhnhankanl ht fff)

Pitchblende

- +... . and Today’s

A comparison of the energy-values of .coal and uranium.
Uranium ore, obtained from pitchblende, consists of both U235
and U238. For every 140 parts of U238 is found one part of U235
which produces uranium fission and releases atomic energy.
U235 is capable of releasing more than a million times as much
energy as its equal weight of coal. Expressed in terms of equal
weights of pitchblende and coal (see above), atomic energy is
represented as 10,000 dots to the single speck of coal-energy.
Extraction of uranium ore from pitchblende and the isolation of
U235 from the ore involve elaborate and expensive processes and
vast industrial plants and the atomic engine for converting
energy into a motive power is still very primitive. In time it

will be improved and atomic energy will be widely available.

Uranium Ore

The atomic engine,’ when perfected, will be self-supporting.
Areas of the world which have remained undeveloped because of
remoteness from sources of coal or oil or hydro-electric power
will be opened up. Chart below (left), shows the distribution of
iron and coal resources according to continents. Each blue sym-
bol represents 5,000,000,000 tons of iron and each black symbol
répresents 250,000,000,000 tons of coal. Hitherto the distri-
bution of industry has coincided with the distribution of iron
and coal. The right-hand chart expresses, in terms of population,
the relative stages of development to-day. Each symbol repre-
sents 50,000,000 population. Red stands for modern industry;
blue for ancient forms of handicraft and green for primitive

‘forms. So while 950,000,000 people have been affected by

modern industry 1,200,000,000 have remained outside its
influences. Atomic energy can provide motive power for industry
anywhere. It will provide power sources for peoples now depend-
ent on handcrafts. It will open up new areas for agricultural
development and raise the living standard of people every-
where. Plastics from growing plants and light metals which are
scattered over the surface of the globe will be developed and will
completely change the world pattern dictated by the coal-iron_
economy. Atomic power can be used to move mountains, change
river courses or create great dams. By changing contours it can
even alter climate. So there’s hope for us yet !

w0010-p0028-00:
Why Neutrons?

An atom is a “‘solar system’’ with
electrons (negative-charged par-
ticles) circling round the nucleus,
which is a combination of protons
(positive-charged particles) and
neutrons without electric charge.

An electron, trying to invade a
uranium atom, is repelled by the
negative charge of the encircling
electrons. (Fig. 1)

A proton can penetrate the

electron-girdle only to be re-

pelled by the positive charge of
the nucleus. (Fig. 2)

1

A neutron (a ‘‘ghost proton’’) having the same mass as a proton
but no charge can penetrate. (Fig. 3)

But it may be travelling so fast that it will pass straight through the
nucleus without producing any change or upheaval. (Fig. 4)

Chain Reaction

At the right speed, it will lodge in the nucleus of either of the uranium
“twins’”’—U238 or U235. Since the stability and character of an
element depends upon the balance between the number of protons
and neutrons in the nucleus, the interloper produces convulsions in
the nucleus. In U238, the upheaval creates a new element, plutonium.
In U235, it causes fission. (Fig. 5)

The atom splits into two, releasing energy and two or more neutrons,
These “‘spare parts’’ in turn split two or more atoms of U235, pro-
ducing a ‘‘chain-reaction.”’ (Fig. 6)

Given the right quantity of pure U235, all the atoms will split each other kK ‘waMmenesgae
in an instantaneous chain-reaction, producing the bomb-explosion.
Plutonium has the same fission-properties and can be used in the bomb.

The Right Speed—Why Heavy Water? enn

A fast neutron in collision with a heavy

obstacle changes its direction but not its

speed. (Fig. 7)
é In collision with a light obstacle, it changes

its direction and loses speed. (Fig. 8)
\ The Heavy Hydrogen atom, found in Heavy
Water, is an obstacle of just the right weight.
While an ordinary Hydrogen atom (Fig. 9)
has only a single proton as its nucleus,
Heavy Hydrogen (Fig. 10) has a proton plus
a neutron as its nucleus and is thus twice as
heavy as a neutron.
In atomic piles, uranium rods can be sus-
pended in Heavy Water. Neutrons, escap-
ing from the rods, cannon off the Heavy
Hydrogen atoms and are bounced back into
the rods, sufficiently slowed down to be
absorbed by the nuclei of either U235 or
U238 (Fig. 11) so helping to sustain fission or
make plutonium. Graphite, consisting of
atoms of carbon, can and in practice is used
instead of Heavy Water.

w0011-p0013-f00:
The Pattern of British Farming

Of the physical factors that condition British farming systems
the most important are rainfall and temperature. The left-
hand map shows the counties which had the highest concen-
trations of cattle and sheep in the 1930's, and the largest
acreages both of the principal cereals and of temporary and
permanent pastures. The dividing line between oats and the
other cereals was determined by the summer temperature;
rainfall determined the boundary between permanent and
temporary grass, Pigs and poultry have been omitted as they
were maintained almost entirely on imported feeding stuffs.

The right-hand map shows the way In which British agri-
culture is likely to develop during the next 25 years. The
new varieties of grass produced by plant-breeders have made
the old boundaries out-of-date. A general extension of
grazing leys would make it possible to double the pre-war
Output of milk without importing more feeding stuffs. Pigs
could also be largely maintained on home-grown food,

w0011-p0046-f01:
HALF A CENTURY OF WORLD SUGAR

At the turn of the century Britain grew no
sugar; she imported Continental beet and
tropical cane. Protected by bounty and cartel,
beet comprised four-sevenths of world output.
European subsidies made prices fluctuate, so
cane producers were in perennial doldrums.

In 1903 the Brussels Convention of European
growers agreed to withdraw export subsidies
in the interest of a free market. Beet output
was rising, but by 1907 cane had drawn level ;
world consumption and production was going
up—but the West Indies, hampered by obso-
lete plant, lagged behind.

World War | held up European production,
while Cuba, aided by American finance, quad-
rupled its output. In 1920, Continental beet
achieved only two-thirds of pre-war produc-
tion. The American continent was growing
nearly half of world caneand U.S.A. had started
beet-growing. Prices rocketed.

In the twenties, owing to intensive research
in Java and the Americas output in tropical
countries rose by half. European beet growers,
aided by subsidies, doubled their output. Prices
fell to 1907 level. Britain bought favoured
Empire sugar and grew subsidised beet.

Result, glutand depression. Sonine countries,
European and tropical, reached agreement on
surpluses, export quotas and price. Cuba and
Java axed production. Continental signatories
trimmed their figures. Yet European output
rose, because U.S.S.R. had trebled her figures.
British Empire sugar doubled in five years.

As drives for self-sufficiency continued,
cane growers were losing markets. In 1937,
first world sugar convention was held, twenty-
one countries reaching agreement on a quota
system to clear surpluses. As the glut began
slowly to disperse, World War II intervened
and changed surplus into critical shortage.

Supplies from Java and Philippines ceased.
Cuba came again to the rescue of America with
almost another million tons a year, but in the
West Indies and elsewhere shortage of ship-
ping, labour and fertilisers reduced exports.
By 1946 all stocks had been cleared and the
European crop was half of normal.

Must glut succeed shortage? With inter-
national agreement there need be no return
to over-production or uneconomic prices.
Prices are being controlled. When output
climbs again, consumption could follow if
millions of people of all colours were brought
nearer to Anglo-American standards of living.
